items.content_html:
While doing the page-type project, we forgot some pages here or there (or they got added right after an area was converted without having a page-type YAML key.

This PR adds the missing page types in the 50-or-so pages that didn't have one. After this PR (and the two others still open), all MDN pages should have a page-type. (A last check will be made before closing the issue).

Note: no new page type is introduced by this PR

This is part of openwebdocs/project#91 and will close #27620.
items.title: Add page-types to remaining pages

items.content_html:
Description

I omitted the last bullet point the Active Learning exercise and revised the exercise's title.

Motivation

Someone pointed it out that adding articles in HTML was not discussed in the earlier parts of the article. Making these edits would make it easier for readers to understand how to do the exercise.

Additional details

Here's the lesson I edited.

Related issues and pull requests

Fixes #27649
items.title: fix: revise active learning exercise

items.content_html:
Description

Fenced frames are an integral part of Google's privacy sandbox technologies. Many parts of this set are being made available by default in Chrome 115 (depending on a gradual ramp up to 100% of userbase over the 115 release period).

This PR provides documentation for the <fencedframe> element and the APIs that underpin it.

See my research document for more details of exactly what changes are expected in the PR.

Motivation

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Add documentation for Fenced Frames

items.content_html:
Description

In the example for the import of the public part of the rsa key there is a small error which prevents the proper base64 decoding. When the part of the pem string is fetched from between the header and the footer, the length of the string is one character too long, a '-' is still trailing. So I added '- 1', then the pem string can be decoded.
I didn' try the importPrivateKey() function for importing the private key, maybe there is the same issue.

Motivation

I use the importRSAKey import in my webview to convert the pem string representation of a public key into a working CryptoKey which I use to encrypt data and send the data to our backend. When I tried to use it I got an error from the atob() function 'Cannot convert base64'. So I tried to fix it and found the solution above. I want to help others who consider using the importRSAKey() function and prevent them from running into the same issue.

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Update index.md

items.content_html:
The page for referrerpolicy on script elements claims it affects "fetches made by the script", but as you can see from the description and example in the specification, it only affects specifically imports made by the script, not all fetches.

This PR fixes the wording to describe what it actually does, per spec.
items.title: Clarify how referrer policy on scripts works

items.content_html:
Add the following page types:

XPath page types

  • xpath-function: a function, like ceiling().

XSLT page types

  • xslt-element: an element of XSLT, like <xsl:message>.
  • xslt-axis: an axis of XSLT, like ancestor.

EXSLT page types

  • xslt-function: a function of EXSLT, like exsl:node-set().

This is part of openwebdocs/project#91
items.title: Add page types for Web/XML, Web/XPath, Web/(E)XSLT

items.title: FF115 Update to link rel=modulepreload

items.content_html:
This adds page types for WebAssembly. I tried to stay as close as possible as the Web APIs page types for the JS API. There are also guide and landing-page, as well as webassembly-instruction for the pages with opcodes.

  • webassembly-function: a global function, that is a method directly under the WebAssembly object that acts as a namespace, like WebAssembly.instantiate().
  • webassembly-constructor: a constructor, like WebAssembly.Exception().
  • webassembly-interface: a WebAssembly interface, like WebAssembly.LinkError.
  • webassembly-instance-property: an instance property, like WebAssembly.Instance.exports.
  • webassembly-instance-method: an instance method, like WebAssembly.Exception.getArg().
  • webassembly-static-method: a static method, like WebAssembly.Module.exports().
  • webassembly-instruction: an instruction, or a set of instructions, like Wrap.

This is a part of openwebdocs/project#91
items.title: Add page types for the WebAssembly section

items.content_html: • Fixes: #27728
items.title: fix(CSS): add a note to table-layout `fixed` value section

items.content_html:
Description

  • This PR defines a template for the CSS module landing pages, such as CSS animations and CSS basic user interface.
  • It also updates the Page types page to add a section and link to the new tenplate

This PR is related to the work being done via openwebdocs/project#147 by @estelle.

Motivation

To define a structure that can be used uniformly to create/update other CSS module landing pages.

Additional details

  • The template in this PR proposes to elevate the "x in action" section to H2 so that it is available from the in-page "In this article" TOC. If this gets accepted, I can update the module landing pages that have already been worked on.
  • Similarly, I can go back to check the 'done' module landing pages to see compliance with the template.
items.title: docs(template): Add template for CSS module landing pages

items.content_html:
Description

On March 2023, a new HTML <search> element was added to the HTML specification.

Fix #26006
Fix mdn/mdn#385

Related issues

  • Safari: https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=254327
  • Firefox: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1824121
  • Chrome: https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1294294, https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1277435
items.title: HTML `<search>` element

items.content_html:
Description

The syntax of the offset-position property has changed.

  • A new keyword (normal) has been added: https://drafts.fxtf.org/motion/#offset-position-property

This PR updates the offset-position property page:

  • Adds the new normal keyword
  • Updates the description of the auto keyword
  • Adds a "Result" frame for the existing example
  • Adds a new example to show the difference in the values of the offset-position property (codepen: https://codepen.io/dipikabh/pen/oNQZyOm)

Caveats

  • Firefox has newly added support for the offset-position property behind the pref layout.css.motion-path-offset-position.enabled.
  • To view the example containing the ray() function, the pref layout.css.motion-path-ray.enabled will also need to be enabled
  • The code example is based on the (expected) behavior I tested in Nightly. I did not see the expected behavior of normal in Firefox beta 115.0b9.

Related issues and pull requests

Doc tracker for this update: #27174
Bug: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1559232

To Dos

  • Update BCD: mdn/browser-compat-data#20250
  • Update release notes: #27730
  • Update mdn/data: mdn/data#673
items.title: docs(css): Fx115 - Update "offset-position" property syntax

items.content_html:
Description

Add additional links to articles talking about styling scrollbars with CSS.

Motivation

When reading a specific article, the reader needs to know that it's part of a set of articles. Additional links to other articles should help the reader understand the bigger context.

As MDN user, I always go to the "See also" section to look for additional articles related to the topic. In scrollbar articles, this information was not sufficient.
items.title: Styling Scrollbars - add links to related articles
